title: Assessing human iPSC-derived microglia identity and function by immunostaining, phagocytosis, calcium activity, and inflammation assay
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Part 1: Immunostaining of microglia marker
Timing: 3 days
Microglia identity can be defined with the following selective markers (Table 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3]):
table:files/protocols_protocol_2171_8.csv
Note: A unique microglia-selective marker has not yet been found. All listed markers also label other cell types such as blood-derived macrophages, perivascular macrophages, and similar . Thus, a combination of validated markers should be used to investigate microglia cell identity.
Note: TMEM119 (transmembrane protein 119) has been described as a microglia-specific marker,24[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib28] and has been used in various studies to confirm microglia identity.7[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7],8[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8],25[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib29] However, when we analyzed non-isolated microglia embedded in mesenchymal tissue, we could not observe TMEM119 expression in microglia-like cells.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1] Due to this ambiguity, we decided against including TMEM119 as a selective marker.
Note: Ideally, the antibodies used for hiPSC-derived microglia-like cells are cross-validated for their specificity in human tissue because several papers only refer to the specificity in mouse tissue. In Bartalska et al.,1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1] we have validated the above set of markers in human brain tissue.
Here, we describe an example immunostaining for IBA1, P2Y12, and PU.1 (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).

(Day 0) Seed collected microglia cells as described in “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin] – seeding cells[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.5]”. Adjust the culture format and the cell number as outlined in Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2].
Incubate cells at 37°C, 5% CO2, overnight (∼15–17 h).

Prepare the solutions formaldehyde solution , blocking solution, and antibody solution.
(Day 1) Fixing microglia-like cells.
Aspirate the medium.
Add 200 μL PBS (phosphate buffered saline) per well to wash the cells.
Aspirate the PBS.
Add 200 μL of 4% (w/v) formaldehyde solution at room temperature (20°C–22°C) per well (troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5]).
Critical: Handle formaldehyde always in a fume hood.
Incubate cells for 15 min in the fixative at room temperature (20°C–22°C).
Collect the formaldehyde solution with a pipette and dispose it in the aldehyde waste disposal.
Critical: Formaldehyde is toxic and requires specific aldehyde waste disposal.
Add 200 μL PBS per well.
Incubate cells for 5 min in PBS.
Aspirate PBS.
Repeat steps 2g–i in total of three times.
Note: The cells can also wash for longer time.
Pause point: Fixed cells can be stored in 200 μL PBS at 4°C for up to 3 months. To prevent evaporation of the PBS, the dish should be wrapped with parafilm.
(Day 1–2) Staining of fixed cells.
Incubate cells in 150 μL blocking solution for two hours at room temperature (20°C–22°C).
Critical: Do not incubate the Ibidi-chamber on a shaker to avoid cell detachment.
Prepare the primary antibodies in diluting the desired antibody concentration in 150 μL antibody solution per well. For an estimate of the dilution factor, see the list of primary antibodies in the key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table].
Well 1: Mix 0.6 μL goat-anti-IBA1 and 1.5 μL rabbit-anti-P2Y12 to get a 1:250 and 1:100 dilution, respectively.
Well 2: Mix 0.6 μL goat-anti-IBA1 and 0.3 μL rabbit-anti-PU.1 to get a 1:250 and 1:500 dilution, respectively.
Note: Due to antibody batch effects, each primary antibody has to be validated for their optimized concentration ideally with testing different dilution factors.
After the 2 h, aspirate the blocking solution.

Add the antibody solution containing the desired primary antibodies.
Incubate the plate overnight (∼15–17 h) at room temperature (20°C–22°C).
Note: It might be beneficial to transfer the plate to 4°C to prevent the denaturation of reagents and evaporation of the solution.
Aspirate the antibody solution.
Perform the washing step described in steps 2g–j.
To perform the secondary antibody staining, prepare in total 300 μL antibody solution and add 0.15 μL goat-anti-Alexa Fluor 488 and 0.15 μL rabbit-anti-Alexa Fluor 647 correlating to a 1:2000 dilution.
Note: Due to antibody batch effects, each secondary antibody has to be validated for their optimized concentration with varying dilution factors.
Note: The fluorophore of the secondary antibodies should be chosen based on the excitation/emission spectra available at the microscope.
Add 150 μL of the secondary antibodies containing antibody solution into each well.
Incubate the cells light-protected for 2 h at room temperature (20°C–22°C).
Critical: Light exposure causes fading of the fluorophore signal. Therefore, the Ibidi-chamber should be either covered with aluminum foil or kept in a box.
Aspirate antibody solution.
Perform the washing step described in steps 2g–j.
To stain the cellular nuclei, dilute 0.1 μL Hoechst 33342 (1:5000) in 500 μL PBS to obtain a Hoechst-PBS solution.
Add 200 μL of the diluted Hoechst-PBS solution per well.
Incubated the cells light-protected for 8 min.
Perform the washing step described in steps 2g–j.
Pause point: The samples can be stored in 200 μL PBS at 4°C in the dark until imaging.
Note: If the samples are stored longer than 1 week, the Ibidi-chamber should be wrapped with parafilm to prevent dry-out of the samples.
(Day 2) Imaging of stained cells.
Place the Ibidi-chamber into the specimen holder of the microscope.

Note: Ibidi-chambers can only be imaged with an inverted microscope. We used a LSM880 inverted confocal microscope. Alternatively, an epifluorescence microscope or a spinning disk confocal microscope can be used.
Set up acquisition parameters on the microscope optimized for the excitation/emission spectra of the secondary antibody.
Use a 20× objective to find the region-of-interest and to determine whether the cells expressed the investigated marker.
Use a 40× oil immersion objective to focus on small subset of microglia to investigate expression details.
Note: To distinguish signal from background, a control sample should be imaged at the same time that has been only stained with the secondary antibody.
Analysis
Timing: up to 15 min
Here, we describe how to process images to take snapshots of the immunostaining of interest.
Software requirements:
Get access to Imaris and obtain a license: https://imaris.oxinst.com/packages[href=https://imaris.oxinst.com/packages].
Convert microscope images to .ims files using the Imaris File Converter (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
Drag and drop the microscope images into the Imaris File Converter.
Press “Start all”.
Open the converted files in Imaris.
Open “Display Adjustment” to visualize individual image channels (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C).
If necessary, process the images by clicking the “Image Processing” icon on the toolbar (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]D).
Process images (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]E).
In the dropdown box of each channel select “Median filter”.
Select the newly generated channel.
Apply “Background Subtraction” for each channel and press “OK”.
Visualize the channel or channels of interest.
Select the icon “Snapshot” (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]F).
Note: As an alternative, the open-source software Fiji/ImageJ can be used.
Part 2: Beads-based phagocytosis assay
Timing: 2 days

Microglia have been shown to phagocytose e.g., apoptotic cells, invading microbes, or synapses.31[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib30],32[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib31],33[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib32] This phagocytic behavior can be recapitulated by quantifying the uptake of beads over time.34[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib33] To visualize microglia in a non-fixed environment, tomato lectin (Lycopersicon esculentum) can be used, which selectively labels human microglia and blood vessels.35[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib34]
(Day 0) Seed collected microglia cells as described in “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin] – seeding cells[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.5]”. Adjust the culture format and the cell number as outlined in Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2]. Incubate cells at 37°C, 5% CO2 overnight (∼15–17 h) (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).

(A) Schematic overview of phagocytosis assay timeline. Min: minutes.
(B–J) Screenshots of Imaris software version 9.9.1. (B) Icon for “Surface rendering” (arrow). (C) Blue icon for “Next” (arrow). (D) Arrows point to: first “Create”, second “Source channel”, third “Surface detail” and fourth “Threshold (Absolute Intensity)”. (E) Adjustment of “Threshold (Absolute Intensity)” (arrow). (Day 1) Preheat the microscope chamber to 37°C.
Note: Depending on the microscope heating chamber, this process will take approximately 30 min. Meanwhile you can proceed with steps 15 and 16.
Note: No CO2 and humidity control is necessary.
Set up the microscope.
Use a 20× air objective.
Activate the 488 nm and 568 nm laser channels.
Set up the microscope so that the two channels 488 nm and 568 nm can be simultaneously imaged and bleed-through is limited.
Set up a time series with 1 cycle/minute and 80 cycles in total.
Activate z-stack option.

Activate an autofocus for each cycle to compensate drifting on the z-axis.
Note: We used a LSM880 inverted confocal microscope. Alternatively, an epifluorescence microscope or a spinning disk confocal microscope can be used.
Staining of attached microglia cells for live cell imaging.
Prepare lectin staining solution by adding 0.2 μL tomato-lectin to 200 μL DBPS.
Pre-warm DPBS, lectin staining solution, and Leibovitz’s L-15 medium to 37°C in a bead bath.
After pre-warming the solutions, aspirate the medium from the Ibidi-chamber.
Wash the cells with 200 μL pre-warmed DPBS.
Aspirate DPBS.
Add 200 μL of the lectin staining solution.
Transfer the cells for 20 min at 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator.
Note: We use a tomato-lectin, which is conjugated to green fluorophore, and the beads are conjugated to a red dye. Alternatively, also other lectins and bead color combinations can be used.
Optional: If the cell line endogenously expressed a fluorophore, the tomato-lectin labeling step can be omitted.
Live cell imaging.
Before imaging, aspirate the lectin staining solution.
Wash the cells with 200 μL DPBS.
Add 390 μL pre-warmed Leibovitz’s L-15 medium.
Protect the stained cells from light and transfer the cells to the microscope.
Place the Ibidi-chamber into the specimen holder.
Select a representative region-of-interest for imaging.
Set a z-stack to acquire the entire volume of the microglia-like cells.
Critical: The autofocus and the acquisition of one z-stack needs to be finished within 1 min. Therefore, you need to adjust the acquisition speed and number of planes.
Before starting the time series, remove the lid of the Ibidi-chamber.
Start recording.
Acquire 20 min of baseline.
Meanwhile, re-suspend beads at 1 mg/mL in pre-warmed Leibovitz’s L-15 medium according to manufacturer’s instructions[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https://assets.thermofisher.com/TFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2Fmp35361.pdf].
Shortly before use, sonicate beads for 30 s at room temperature (20°C–22°C) to homogenously disperse particles.

After the acquisition of cycle 20, immediately add 10 μL of freshly sonicated beads in Leibovitz’s L-15 medium to the Ibidi-chamber without stopping the recording.
Critical: Avoid touching the Ibidi-chamber while adding the beads to prevent the loss of the region-of-interest. Therefore, the lid should be removed before starting the acquisition.
Note: It is not necessary to re-suspend the solution since we perform a qualitative description and thus the beads do not need to be equally distributed.
Keep recording for the remaining 60 min to image the bead uptake.
In total, repeat the assay three times from three independent differentiations.
Analysis
Timing: up to 30 min
In the following example, we describe how to quantify the microglia uptake of beads as a parameter of phagocytic activity.
Software requirements:
Get access to Imaris and obtain a license: https://imaris.oxinst.com/packages[href=https://imaris.oxinst.com/packages].
To perform the described analysis, the surface rendering function is required.
Get access to R here: https://www.rstudio.com/[href=https://www.rstudio.com/].
For opening and processing the images see steps 6–10. Then apply “Median Filter” and “Background Subtraction (local contrast)” to both channels. Visualize the microglia channel.
Click the icon “Surface rendering” to create a new surface (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B).
In the newly opened window press the blue icon for “Next” (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C).
Create the surface of microglia (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]D).
Select the “Create” tab.
In “Source channel”, select the channel that labels microglia.
Enter the surface detail resolution and keep it consistent across the experiment. In our analysis, we used a surface detail of 0.2 μm.
Note: Imaris is automatically adjusting the value in function of the resolution.
Select ‘‘Absolut intensity’’ as the thresholding method.
Press the blue icon for “Next” (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C).
Adjust the threshold with the slider to visualize microglia surface and minimize background. Use the microglia channel as a reference (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]E).

Press the green button for “Finish” (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]F).
Note: This step creates the surface of the microglia-like cells (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]G).
Next, determine the intensity mean of the 568 nm channel within the microglia-like cell created surfaces. For this, open the statistics of the created surfaces (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]H).
Select the newly generated “Surface 1” tab.
Select the “Statistics” icon.
Four new tabs will appear (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]I).
Select “Detailed”.
Select “Average Values”.
Select “Intensity Mean Ch=2 Img=1”.
Select the icon “Export data for plotting” and export data as .xlsx (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]J).
To visualize the exported data use e.g., R.
Note: We used the xlsx package21[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib20] to load the excel file into R, the ggplot2 package22[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib21] to generate plots, and geom_abline() to visualized the 95% confidence interval.
Part 3: Imaging calcium activity after ATP stimulation
Timing: 2 days
Intracellular calcium (Ca2+) has been shown to modulate various microglia properties such as proliferation, migration, and phagocytosis.36[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib35] ATP (adenosin-tri-phosphat) is an important modulator of microglial Ca2+-signaling by activating specific ionotropic and metabotropic purinergic receptors.37[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib36],38[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib37] Here, we determine the activity of microglia-like cells based on fluctuations in intracellular Ca2+-events upon stimulation with ATP.
Note: Fluo-4 is an easy-to-use synthetic Ca2+-indicator39[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib38] and suitable for live cell imaging of microglia.40[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib39] Spontaneous and ligand stimulated changes in intracellular Ca2+-levels can be assessed with high sensitivity.
(Day 0) Seed collected microglia cells as described in “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin] – seeding cells[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.5]”. Adjust the culture format and the cell number as outlined in Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2].
Incubate cells at 37°C, 5% CO2 overnight (∼15–17 h) (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A).

(Day 1) Prepare 1× Fluo-4 Ca2+-assay solution according to manufacturer’s instructions[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/order/catalog/product/F10471] and pre-warm 550 μL to 37°C in a bead bath to stain 2 wells of the Ibidi-chamber.
Note: Reconstituted Fluo-4 Ca2+-assay solution can be aliquoted and stored for 2 weeks at −20°C.
Prepare 200 μL of 10 mM ATP in Leibovitz’s L-15 medium.
Label attached microglia-like cells with the 1× Fluo-4 Ca2+-assay solution.
Aspirate the medium.

Add 250 μL of 1× Fluo-4 Ca2+-assay solution per well.
Incubate cells at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 30 min.
Remove cells from the incubator, protect the cells from light, and incubate them at room temperature (20°C–22°C) for another 30 min as suggested by the manufacturer’s recommendation[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/order/catalog/product/F10471] for other cell types.
Aspirate 1× Fluo-4 Ca2+-assay solution.
Add 270 μL of pre-warmed Leibovitz’s L-15 medium.
Note: Label both wells of the Ibidi-chamber simultaneously.
Set up the microscope and image calcium activity.
Place the Ibidi-chamber into the specimen holder.
Activate the 488 nm laser channel.
Use a 20× air objective.
Select an area with around 50 cells per field-of-view.
Set a time series with 1 cycle/500 ms and a total recording time of 360 s.
Before starting the acquisition, remove the lid of the Ibidi-chamber.
Record 180 s/360 frames of baseline activity.
Immediately afterwards, add 30 μL of the ATP in Leibovitz’s L-15 medium into the well for a final ATP concentration of 1 mM.
Continue the acquisition for the following 180 s.
Note: To minimize photo bleaching, reduce laser power and gain. We used 0.5% laser power of a 25 mW Argon-Multiline laser and a gain of 500 (troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7]).
Note: Do not stop recording while applying ATP.
Critical: To prevent the loss of the region-of-interest, avoid touching the Ibidi-chamber with the tip while adding ATP. Therefore, the lid should be removed before starting the acquisition. Pipette the ATP solution carefully onto the surface of medium. Do not re-suspend the medium.
To obtain a control, repeat steps 35d–i for the second well. Instead of ATP, add Leibovitz’s L-15 medium at step 35h.
In total, repeat the assay three times from three independent differentiations.

Timing: 1 h

Here we describe a method to visualize Ca2+ events occurring in single microglia-like cells with and without stimulation.
Software requirements:
Get access to Fiji/ImageJ here: https://imagej.net/software/fiji/[href=https://imagej.net/software/fiji/].
Get access to R studio here: https://www.rstudio.com/[href=https://www.rstudio.com/].

Select “Macros”.
Select “Record”.
The “Recorder” window appears (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]E).
Apply a Gaussian Blur to the image (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]F).

Select “Filters”.
Choose “Gaussian Blur”.
Adjust the parameters (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]G).

Select “OK”.

Select “LUT”.
Choose one of the listed options.

Save the macro code in the “Recorder” window (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]I).
Batch process the images (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]J).
Select the “Process” tab.
Choose “Batch”.
Select “Macro”.
The “Batch Process” window opens (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]K).
Select the “Input” directory.
Select the “Output” directory.
Insert the macro code into the empty field.
Select “Process” to start the batch processing.
Set analysis parameters (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]L).
Select the “Analyze” tab.
Choose “Set measurements”.
The “Set measurements” window opens (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]M).
Select “Mean grey values”.
Press “OK”.
Open processed file and select your regions of interest (ROIs) (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]N).

Open file and select the “Analyze” tab.
Go to “Tools”.
Choose “ROI Manager”.
Manually select ROIs (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]O).
Select ROIs on the center of individual cells using an elliptic shape.
Select “Add” to have the ROI listed.

Repeat step 52b for all cells of interest.

Select “More” and “Multi Measure” in the ROI manager to measure the mean grey value for each ROI.
Activate the two options: “Measure all slices” and “One row per slice” in the “Multi measure” window.
Press “OK”.
Export the “Mean intensity values”.
To visualize the exported data use e.g., R.
Note: We used the xlsx package21[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib20] to load the excel file into R, the ggplot2 package22[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib21] to generate plots. We normalized the intensity of each cell to its average intensity throughout the entire 360 s of recording and performed a one-sample t-test to compare different conditions.
Optional: An alternative approach is PeakCaller, a MATLAB script that can be used for the quantification of intracellular Ca2+-transients.23[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib22] The output provides various parameters describing the peaks such as amplitude, frequency, rise and decay time and the half maximum width. We used this script to quantify and visualize the sum of Ca2+-events occurring in microglia-like cells within experimental conditions over the whole duration of recording. We used following parameters: required rise = 20% absolute; max. lookback = 700 pts; required fall = 30% absolute; max. lookahead = 700 pts; trend control = exponential moving average (2-sided); trend smoothness = 100; interpolate across closed shutters = true.
Critical: PeakCaller detects peaks which are not reflecting Ca2+-events. For this reason, we additionally filtered the output in R by including only peaks with a height >0.15 and a FWHM >5.

Part 4: Inflammation assay
Timing: 2 days
Pathological conditions caused by injuries or infections increase the expression of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IL1β, IL-6 and TNFα in microglia.33[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib32] In this protocol, we identify changes in the mRNA transcript levels in response to inflammatory stimuli. To treat microglia, a combination of IFNy and IL1β,33[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib32] bacterial lipopolysaccharide (LPS)41[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib40] or polyinosinic:polycytidylic acid (poly I:C)42[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib41] can be used.
Before starting the experiment, order primers. Alternatively, primers can be also designed for the gene-of-interest.
Download the RNA sequence of your gene-of-interest from e.g., NCBI[href=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gene].
Copy the sequence into Primer-Blast[href=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/tools/primer-blast/].
Set the product length to 70–200 base pairs (bp).
Keep the default settings.
Choose a primer pair based on the following parameters:
Primer length: 18–24 bp.
G/C content: 40%–60%.
Tm (melting temperature): 50°C–60°C.
Avoid self-complimentary structures (<8).
Avoid cross-dimer formation (<5).
Order Primers.
Validate primers.
Run a RT-qPCR of a test sample (e.g., untreated harvested microglia-like cells) and check the PCR product size by running an agarose gel.
Run a RT-qPCR on serial dilutions of your test sample to check the efficiency.
(Day 0) Seed collected microglia cells as described in “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin] – seeding cells[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.5]”. Adjust the culture format and the cell number as outlined in Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2] and incubate cells at 37°C, 5% CO2 overnight (∼15–17 h) (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).

Figure 5. Inflammation assay

(Day 1) Pre-warm 2,000 μL microglia medium for 4 wells.

Isolate RNA with innuPREP RNA Mini Kit 2.0 as described in the manufacturer’s instructions[href=https://www.analytik-jena.fr/fileadmin/content/pdf_life_science/Manual/Manual_innuPREP_DNA_RNA_Mini_Kit.pdf].

Analysis
Timing: 1 h

With this step you will analyze the fold changes in inflammatory gene expression levels of treated and untreated microglia-like cells.45[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib44]
Export Cq values from the Lightcycler 480 software into an excel file.
Calculate the mean Cq values from the three technical replicates for each gene (Equation 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fd1]).
   (Equation 1)    C q  ( m e a n )  =   Cq   ( 1 )  + Cq   ( 2 )  + Cq   ( 3 )   3      
Calculate the standard deviation for the mean Cq values for each gene.
Remove technical replicates with a standard deviation larger than 0.5.
Calculate the geometric mean of the four reference genes (Equation 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fd2]).
   (Equation 2)   C q   ( R E F  m e a n )  =   C q   (  R E F 1  )  ∗ C q   (  R E F 2  )  ∗ C q   (  R E F 3  )  ∗ C q   ( R E F 4 )   4      
Calculate ΔCq values (Equation 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fd3]): normalize mean Cq values of all genes of interest to the geometric mean of the reference genes measured within the same sample.
   (Equation 3)   Δ Cq  =  Cq   ( geometric mean of reference gene )    -  Cq   ( gene of interest )      
Calculate ΔΔCq values (Equation 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fd4]): normalize ΔCq values of treated samples to untreated control condition within each experimental repetition.
   (Equation 4)   Δ Δ Cq  =   Δ Cq   ( Treated )    -   Δ Cq   ( Untreated )      
Transform ΔΔCq values from log2-scale (Equation 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fd5]) to describe fold changes between the treated and untreated group.
   (Equation 5)   F o l d  c h a n g e   ( g e n e  e x p r e s s i o n )  =   2  −  ( Δ Δ C q )

Use e.g., the software R to visualize and analyze the data.
To compare the stimulated condition with its untreated control, perform one-sample t-test and adjust for multiple testing using the Benjamini-Hochberg method.
